bibl.title: Letter from Samuel T. Darling to Frederick F. Russell, September 18, 1923

div1.p: Darling has examined the slides from the suspected yellow fever patient.

div1.head: Letter from Samuel T. Darling to Frederick F. Russell, September 18, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
Leesburg, Ga.
September 18, 1923
Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway
New York City
Dear Dr. Russell:
div1.p:
The slides from the case of suspected yellow fever which
died at Colima, Mexico, Senior Luis B. Corona certified as having
died of yellow fever at Colima August 21, 1923, have been received
and I have gone over them carefully.

The post-mortem changes are advanced and I strongly sus-
pect that the patient had been dead longer than fifteen hours. In
spite of the post-mortem decomposition it is very plain that the
liver is the seat of extensive cirrhosis. The connective tissue
around the portal spaces is often fibrous and increased in amount with
coarse prolongations extending up between the columns of hepatic cells.
Associated with this is a proliferation of the bile ducts as in biliary
cirrhosis, and there is a very large amount of fatty infiltration, the
fat droplets being usually of large size. Nowhere do I find the fat
existing in the minute intracellular droplets usually seen in yellow
fever. The endothetial cells lining the sinusoids contain black gran-
ules resembling malarial pigment. Everywhere there is an invasion of
the tissue by a rather large sized bacillus.

On account of the extreme post-mortem changes and the in-
fluence of this on the tinctorial reaction of the cells with eosin and
haematoxylin, it would be hazardous to say that the patient had not
had yellow fever but the symptoms of jaundice and the presence of blood
in the nasal passages can all be explained by the lesions associated
with cirrhosis already described.
div1.closer: Yours very truly, (Signed) Samuel T. Darling D/H
